bibl.author: John M. Rogers
bibl.title: John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 27 February 1871
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

body.p:
I receivereceived your letter on Saturday and was glad to hear from you and that you are well and enjoying youyour self I am as well as ever but I feel very uneasy at times because I am doing nothing I have not done any thing scince Jan 1st every thing is very dull here at presantpresent The weather is warm and pleasant here for this time of the
year We did not have a very great time on Washington birth day here a reg. or two of Soldiers turned out in a parade was all that I see in this great City I should like very much to come to WashintonWashington and see you but as long as I know that you are well and enjoying your self I will try to content my self It rained all day here yesterday and I did not go out any wharewhere I feel very greatfulgrateful to you that you should take so much interistinterest in me it makes
me think of my father all though if we think of our dear heavenly FatheFather he will guide and direct us in all our ways and we ought to be very thankful to him for our good health he is such a good Father to us so good bybye for the presantpresent my Dear good Father

postscript.p: P.S. I would come out there on a visit but can not afordafford it just now so good bybye
